thread.title: Beaverton auto magnate Bob Lanphere Sr. dies at 81
thread.title_full: Beaverton auto magnate Bob Lanphere Sr. dies at 81 | OregonLive.com

author: Anna Marum | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Beaverton auto magnate Bob Lanphere Sr. dies at 81
text:
Bob Lanphere Sr., who helped establish Beaverton as a car dealership destination, died on Friday while on a cruise. He was 81.
Lanphere lived to see his first company, Beaverton Honda Motorcycles, celebrate its 50th anniversary last year.
He bought his first motorcycle after leaving the U.S. Army in 1955, and opened the motorcycle shop at Southwest Broadway and Hall, in the heart of downtown Beaverton, in 1964.
Since, Lanphere grew his company, renamed Lanphere Enterprises, to include multiple car dealerships and a construction company.
Throughout its growth, the company remained family-owned: Lanphere's son, Bob Lanphere Jr., is president of Lanphere Enterprises, and his daughter Sharon Lenz and granddaughter Rachel Lenz also hold positions.
Lanphere Enterprises' corporate headquarters remains in downtown Beaverton, and the company employs more than 800 people throughout the Northwest.
Beaverton Mayor Denny Doyle said he met Lanphere about 20 years ago, and said he's thankful for the businessman's role as a proponent for the community.
"The jobs that he and his company have provided to Beaverton are priceless," he said.
Lanphere, along with other area car dealership owners, helped make Beaverton what it is today, Doyle said.
"It's just amazing," Doyle said of the dealerships' contribution. "They've been very faithful to this community. People like Guy Carr (former owner of Carr Chevrolet), Randy Francis (former owner of Damerow Beaverton Ford), Mike Herzog (of Herzog-Meier Volvo) â€” everybody has been involved for 40, 50 years, and [the dealerships] are all still here. They all have a lot of impact."
In addition to providing jobs, Lanphere Enterprises regularly sponsored local events, like the Beaverton Celebration Parade.
"He was a great guy," said Doyle, who occasionally played golf with Lanphere. "I'm going to miss seeing him."
-- Anna Marum
amarum@oregonian.com
503-294-5911
@annamarum
Oregonian reporter Laura Frazier contributed to this story.
